Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Joseph Byrnes of the University of Oregon to conduct a research project in Geoscience during the summer of 2013 at the Earthquake Research Institute, University of Tokyo in Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo. The project title is "Using Recordings of Distant Earthquakes to Measure the Thickness of Tectonic Plates." The host scientist is Professor Hitoshi Kawakatsu.

It has recently been shown that a sharp discontinuity in seismic velocity exists at the bottom of tectonic plates in the ocean. This discontinuity is postulated to distinguish the rigid plate (the 'Lithosphere') from the underlying convective mantle (the 'Asthenosphere'). The reason the discontinuity exists is poorly understood. This project aims to measure the depth of the discontinuity with plate age using ocean bottom seismometers located on the Juan De Fuca Plate, just off the coast of the Pacific Northwest. Since the discontinuity is sharp, P and S waves from distant events convert into one another when passing through the plate. The difference in arrival time, due to the lower velocity of S waves, between the direct and converted phases gives the depth to the discontinuity. Using this technique, the evolution of this enigmatic boundary can be established. Several competing theories have been put forward to explain why this discontinuity exists. The simplest hypothesis is that the plate thickness grows as the square root of its age, as predicted by models of a plate growing by conductive cooling. The most likely alternative is that the discontinuity has constant depth and is independent of age, which would likely represented a plate defined by the removal of water from the mantle when the plate is created, forming a rigid body that defines the tectonic plate.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the Fellow hopes to establish relationships that produce scientific results beyond the summer. The research done during the funding period will lay the groundwork for future collaboration between researchers in the U.S. and Japan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I am a graduate student at the University of Oregon, and I worked with Professor Hitoshi Kawakatsu at the Earthquake Research Center of the University of Tokyo. We analysed data from ocean bottom seismometers (OBS) deployed on the bottom of the Philippine sea in an attempt to understand the pattern of mantle flow beneath the oceans. Plate tectonics hinges on the idea that the upper most mantle consists of a cold, ridge plate (called the lithosphere) that slides around the surface of the planet over a weak, fluid-like layer (called the asthenosphere). As the lithosphere moves, it shears the asthenosphere and aligns minerals in the direction of the plate's motion. This mineral 'fabric' can deform shear waves in fairly well understood way. Therefore, we can study the fabric of the mantle beneath the oceans by analyzing shear waves (the technique is called 'shear wave splitting') observed by OBSs. We expected that the fabric would be lined up with the direction of plate motion, but misalignment would be an interesting sign of deeper fabrics, anomlous mantle flow, or fabric within the plate itself. The main difficulty is that a seismometer is basically a motion detector - and the oceans never sit still. Seismic waves are notoriously difficult to observe the oceans, but shear wave splitting with OBS data can and has been done. The shear waves we are looking for don't have a very high amplitude, and proved difficult to observe above the noise in the data caused by ocean currents rocking the instrument. Professor Kawakatsu and I looked over the course of a couple months for high-amplitude shear waves (SKS or ScS phases) but weren't able to find any with a high enough signal to noise ratio. A number of shear waves had amplitudes that were quite close to useable, but the results were so inconsistent that we could not get an understanding of the fabric beneath the Philippine sea. All is not lost, however, since I did gain a useful understanding of the commonly used software for shear wave splitting (Splitlab) and developed some scripts of my own that another student in my lab back in Oregon was able to use. Beyond this, I gained a deeper understanding of the field from my time spent with the extremely knowledgeable Professor Kawakatsu and consider my time in Japan an invaluable part of my graduate education.
